statement.tex: %text A metal ball bearing of diameter $42$cm is melted and drawn into a wire of diameter $28$cm. What would be the length of the wire if $20$\% of the metal was lost. %
\\ %text If the ball bearing is of diameter $42$cm, is the following the correct expression for its volume? %
\\ %text If $20$\% of the original $\dfrac{4}{3}\pi\cdot 21^3(cm)^3$ of metal from the ball bearing was lost in melting, how much metal by volume remains for the wire? %
\\ %text If $\dfrac{16}{15}\pi\cdot 21^3(cm)^3$ of metal is available for drawing into a wire of $28$ cm diameter, what would the length of such a wire be? %

reason.tex: %text Volume of a sphere of radius $r$ is $\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3$ %
%text $20$\% by volume was lost therefore $80$\% or four-fifths still remains. % \quad V=\dfrac{4}{5}\cdot \dfrac{4}{3}\pi\cdot 21^3(cm)^3= \dfrac{16}{15}\pi\cdot 21^3(cm)^3

%text The volume of a wire of length $l$ and radius $r$ is given by ${\bf\pi \cdot r^2l}$. Equating this with volume of metal remaining we get, % \begin{align} &\dfrac{16}{15}\pi\cdot 21^3(cm)^3=\pi \cdot \left(\dfrac{28}{2}\right)^2\cdot l\,(cm)^3 \\ \implies &\dfrac{16}{15}\pi\cdot 21^3(cm)^3=\pi \cdot 14^2\cdot l\,(cm)^3 \\ \implies &l=\dfrac{16\times 7^3\times 3^3}{15\times 7^2\times 2^2} =\dfrac{4\times 7\times 3^2}{5}=50.4cm \end{align}
